prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. The friend, G, didn't send a save-the-date and only sent invitations a month before the wedding. The author and friends had planned a trip to Australia, starting two days before the wedding, which they couldn't cancel due to financial reasons. G is upset that they didn't cancel their trip.

First, I need to consider the norms around weddings. Typically, save-the-dates are sent out several months in advance, sometimes up to a year, so that guests can plan their schedules. G sent the invites just a month out, which is pretty short notice. The author and their friends had already planned a significant trip months ago, which they couldn't just drop without financial loss. 

The key points here are the timing of the invitations and the prior commitments. Since the author had informed G about the trip and she still sent the invites too late, it's a bit on G for not being considerate enough. Also, the fact that only 20 out of 50 invited guests can make it suggests that the notice period was indeed too short. 

The author isn't obligated to cancel a planned trip, especially one that's been organized with friends and involves financial commitment. It's understandable that they can't just drop everything last-minute. The author's friends are also in the same boat, which shows it's a collective decision, not just the author's. 

G's reaction seems disproportionate. While it's natural to be disappointed, expecting others to cancel a major trip at short notice isn't reasonable, especially when the notice wasn't given in a timely manner. The author isn't in the wrong here because they made their plans known and G didn't provide enough time to adjust. 

So, the answer should be B (No, the author isn't in the wrong) because the responsibility lies with G for not giving adequate notice and not considering the guests' prior commitments.
